maml:description.maml:para: Exports a guardian that contains public keys.
The `Export-HgsGuardian` cmdlet exports a guardian that contains public keys to an `.xml` file.
Specifies the input to this cmdlet.
You can use this parameter, or you can pipe the input to this cmdlet.
Specifies the path to the file to write an XML representation of the guardian.
Specifies the input to this cmdlet.
You can use this parameter, or you can pipe the input to this cmdlet.
Specifies the path to the file to write an XML representation of the guardian.

maml:introduction.maml:para: ```powershell Get-HgsGuardian -Name 'Guardian11' | Export-HGsGuardian -Path 'C:\LocalHGSFiles\Guardian11.xml' ```

This command uses the `Get-HgsGuardian` cmdlet to get the guardian named `Guardian11`, and then passes the object to the current cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. That cmdlet exports the guardian to the specified file.

maml:description.maml:para: Grants access to a guardian for a key protector.
The `Grant-HgsKeyProtectorAccess` cmdlet grants a Host Guardian Service guardian access to a key protector. This operation requires the private signing key of the owner of the key protector.
Indicates that this cmdlet can grant permissions to a guardian that contains certificates that are expired.
Indicates that this cmdlet can grant permissions to a guardian that uses self-signed certificates.
Specifies a guardian to which to grant access to the key.
Specifies the key protector to which to grant access.
Indicates that this cmdlet can grant permissions to a guardian that contains certificates that are expired.
Indicates that this cmdlet can grant permissions to a guardian that uses self-signed certificates.
Specifies a friendly name for the guardian.
Specifies the key protector to which to grant access.
Indicates that this cmdlet can grant permissions to a guardian that contains certificates that are expired.
Indicates that this cmdlet can grant permissions to a guardian that uses self-signed certificates.
Specifies a guardian to which to grant access to the key.
Specifies a friendly name for the guardian.
Specifies the key protector to which to grant access.

The **Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance** object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (`#`) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

command:example.maml:title: --------- Example 1: Grant access to a guardian ---------

maml:introduction.maml:para: ```powershell $Owner = Get-HgsGuardian -Name "Guardian06" $Guardian01 = Get-HgsGuardian -Name "Guardian11" $KeyProtector = New-HgsKeyProtector -Owner $Owner Grant-HgsKeyProtectorAccess -KeyProtector $KeyProtector -Guardian $Guardian01 ```
The first command gets the guardian object named `Guardian06` by using the `Get-HgsGuardian` cmdlet, and then stores that object in the `$Owner` variable.
The second commands get the guardian object named `Guardian11`, and then stores it in the `$Guardian01` variable.
The third command creates a key protector. The command defines `Guardian06`, stored in `$Owner`, as the **Owner**.
The final command grants access to the guardian stored in `$Guardian01` for the key protector.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a guardian object from an .xml file.

The **Import-HgsGuardian** cmdlet creates a Host Guardian Service guardian object from an .xml file. If you specify a name for the guardian, this cmdlet also persists that object in the local guardian store.
Indicates whether to allow guardian creation with certificates that are expired.
Indicates whether to allow a guardian to be created using self-signed certificates.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies the name to associate with this guardian when it is persisted to the local guardian store.
Specifies the path to an XML file containing the Guardian information.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Indicates whether to allow guardian creation with certificates that are expired.
Indicates whether to allow a guardian to be created using self-signed certificates.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies the name to associate with this guardian when it is persisted to the local guardian store.
Specifies the path to an XML file containing the Guardian information.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

The `Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance` object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (`#`) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

maml:introduction.maml:para: ``` PS C:\> Import-HgsGuardian -Path "C:\MyDirectory\Guardian11.xml" -Name "Guardian11" ```
This command imports a guardian from the specified .xml file.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a Host Guardian Service guardian.

The **New-HgsGuardian** cmdlet creates a cryptographic entity called a Host Guardian Service guardian. A guardian is a principal that you can grant access to the key that is contained in a key protector.
Indicates that this cmdlet can create a guardian by using certificates that are expired.
Indicates that this cmdlet can create a guardian by using self-signed certificates.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies the path of a .pfx file that contains a password protected encryption certificate for the guardian. This .pfx file contains the public and private keys.
Specifies the password to decrypt the .pfx file that contains the encryption certificate.
Specifies a name for the new guardian.
Specifies the path of a .pfx file that contains a password protected signing certificate for the guardian. This .pfx file contains the public and private keys.
Specifies the password necessary to decrypt the signing certificate .pfx file.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Indicates that this cmdlet can create a guardian by using certificates that are expired.
Indicates that this cmdlet can create a guardian by using self-signed certificates.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies the encryption certificate thumbprint.
Specifies a name for the new guardian.
Specifies the thumbprint of a signing certificate located in the local computer certificate store.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Indicates that this cmdlet generates self-signed signing and encryption certificates for the guardian. The certificates contain the public and private keys.
If you specify this parameter, the new guardian does not have a trusted root. Therefore, you must also specify the **AllowUntrustedRoot** parameter.
Specifies a name for the new guardian.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Indicates that this cmdlet can create a guardian by using certificates that are expired.
Indicates that this cmdlet can create a guardian by using self-signed certificates.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies the path of a .pfx file that contains a password protected encryption certificate for the guardian. This .pfx file contains the public and private keys.
Specifies the password to decrypt the .pfx file that contains the encryption certificate.
Specifies the encryption certificate thumbprint.
Indicates that this cmdlet generates self-signed signing and encryption certificates for the guardian. The certificates contain the public and private keys.
If you specify this parameter, the new guardian does not have a trusted root. Therefore, you must also specify the **AllowUntrustedRoot** parameter.
Specifies a name for the new guardian.
Specifies the path of a .pfx file that contains a password protected signing certificate for the guardian. This .pfx file contains the public and private keys.
Specifies the password necessary to decrypt the signing certificate .pfx file.
Specifies the thumbprint of a signing certificate located in the local computer certificate store.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

The `Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance` object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (`#`) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

maml:introduction.maml:para: ``` PS C:\> New-HgsGuardian -Name "Guardian11" -GenerateCertificates ```

This command creates a Host Guardian Service guardian named Guardian11. This guardian can act as owner for a key protector. Because this command specifies the **GenerateCertificates** parameter, it generates signing and encryption certificates.

command:example.maml:title: --------- Example 2: Create a guardian by using existing certificates ---------

maml:introduction.maml:para: ``` PS C:\> $SecureStringPassword01 = ConvertTo-SecureString "<Password01>" -AsPlainText -Force PS C:\> $SecureStringPassword02 = ConvertTo-SecureString "<Password02>" -AsPlainText -Force PS C:\> New-HgsGuardian -Name "Guardian21" -SigningCertificate "C:\Keys\SigningCertificate.pfx" -SigningCertificatePassword $SecureStringPassword01 -EncryptionCertificate "C:\Keys\EncryptionCertificate.pfx" -EncryptionCertificatePassword $SecureStringPassword02 ```

The first two commands create passwords, as secure strings, by using the **ConvertTo-SecureString** cmdlet. For more information, type `Get-Help ConvertTo-SecureString`. The commands store the passwords in two variables.

The final command creates a guardian named Guardian21. The command specifies the necessary signing and encryption certificates as password protected .pfx files. The passwords stored in the **$SecureStringPassword01** and **$SecureStringPassword02** must match the passwords used to generate the .pfx files.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a key protector.

The **New-HgsKeyProtector** cmdlet creates a key protector. This cmdlet generates a key and wraps it for the specified guardian owner. You cannot change the owner for this key protector. You can grant or revoke access to the key for other guardians by using the **Grant-HgsKeyProtectorAccess** and **Revoke-HgsKeyProtectorAccess** cmdlets.
This cmdlet can create a key protector based on the raw byte stream of an existing key protector.
Indicates that this cmdlet can create a key protector by using certificates that are expired.
Indicates that this cmdlet can create a key protector by using self-signed certificates.
Specifies an array of guardians to grant access to the key in addition to the guardian specified by the **Owner** parameter.
Specifies a guardian for the new key protector. The cmdlet grants access to this guardian. This guardian cannot be changed for this key protector.
Indicates that this cmdlet can create a key protector by using certificates that are expired.
Indicates that this cmdlet can create a key protector by using self-signed certificates.
Specifies an array of guardians to grant access to the key in addition to the guardian specified by the **Owner** parameter.
Specifies a guardian for the new key protector. The cmdlet grants access to this guardian. This guardian cannot be changed for this key protector.

The `Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance` object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (`#`) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

maml:introduction.maml:para: ``` PS C:\> $Owner = Get-HgsGuardian -Name "Guardian11" PS C:\> $GuardianA = Get-HgsGuardian -Name "GuardianA" PS C:\> $GuardianB = Get-HgsGuardian -Name "GuardianB" PS C:\> New-HgsKeyProtector -Owner $Owner -Guardians @($GuardianA, $GuardianB) ```
The first command gets the guardian object named Guardian11 by using the **Get-HgsGuardian** cmdlet, and then stores that object in the **$Owner** variable.
The second and third commands get two guardians named GuardianA and GuardianB. These commands store the guardians in the **$GuardianA** and **$GuardianB** variables.
The final command creates a key protector. The command defines Guardian11 as the **Owner**. The command also grants access to the guardians stored in **$GuardianA** and **$GuardianB**.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a guardian from the guardian store.
The **Remove-HgsGuardian** cmdlet removes a Host Guardian Service guardian object from the guardian store.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the guardian to remove.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The HGS guardian object to remove.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
The HGS guardian object to remove.
Specifies the name of the guardian to remove.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

maml:introduction.maml:para: ``` PS C:\> Remove-HgsGuardian -Name "Guardian11" ```
This command removes the guardian named Guardian11 from the local store.

maml:description.maml:para: Revokes access for a guardian to a key protector.
The **Revoke-HgsKeyProtectorAccess** cmdlet revokes access for a Host Guardian Service guardian to a key protector. This operation requires access to private signing key of the owner.
Specifies a guardian from which to revoke access to the key.
Specifies the key protector for which to revoke access.
Specifies a friendly name for a guardian.
Specifies the key protector for which to revoke access.
Specifies a guardian from which to revoke access to the key.
Specifies a friendly name for a guardian.
Specifies the key protector for which to revoke access.

The `Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance` object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (`#`) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

command:example.maml:title: --------- Example 1: Revoke access for a guardian ---------

maml:introduction.maml:para: ``` PS C:\> $Owner = Get-HgsGuardian -Name "Guardian11" PS C:\> $GuardianA = Get-HgsGuardian -Name "GuardianA" PS C:\> $GuardianB = Get-HgsGuardian -Name "GuardianB" PS C:\> New-HgsKeyProtector -Owner $Owner -Guardians @($GuardianA, $GuardianB) PS C:\> $Guardian04 = Get-HgsGuardian -Name "GuardianA" PS C:\> Revoke-HgsKeyProtectorAccess -KeyProtector $KeyProtector -Guardian $Guardian04 ```
The first command gets the guardian object named Guardian11 by using the **Get-HgsGuardian** cmdlet, and then stores that object in the **$Owner** variable.
The second and third commands get two guardians named GuardianA and GuardianB. These commands store the guardians in the **$GuardianA** and **$GuardianB** variables.
The fifth command gets the guardian object named GuardianA, and then stores that object in the **$Guardian04** variable.
The final command revokes access for the guardian stored in **$Guardian04** for the key protector.

maml:description.maml:para: Modifies the configuration of a Host Guardian Service client.

The **Set-HgsClientConfiguration** cmdlet modifies the configuration of a Host Guardian Service client. You can configure the client in either local mode or Host Guardian Service mode. In local mode, there is no attestation and the client keeps key material.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Indicates that this cmdlet changes the mode of client from Host Guardian Service to Local mode. A change in mode to Local resets the attestation server and key protection server URLs.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the URL of an attestation server. A Host Guardian Service client in Secure Hosting Service mode uses the server that this parameter specifies.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies the URL of an attestation server to use if the primary attestation server cannot be reached.
Specifies the URL of a key protection server to use if the primary attestation server cannot be reached.
Specifies the URL of a key protection server. A Host Guardian Service client in Secure Hosting Service mode uses the server that this parameter specifies.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the URL of an attestation server. A Host Guardian Service client in Secure Hosting Service mode uses the server that this parameter specifies.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies the URL of a key protection server. A Host Guardian Service client in Secure Hosting Service mode uses the server that this parameter specifies.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the URL of an attestation server. A Host Guardian Service client in Secure Hosting Service mode uses the server that this parameter specifies.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Indicates that this cmdlet changes the mode of client from Host Guardian Service to Local mode. A change in mode to Local resets the attestation server and key protection server URLs.
Specifies the URL of an attestation server to use if the primary attestation server cannot be reached.
Specifies the URL of a key protection server to use if the primary attestation server cannot be reached.
Specifies the URL of a key protection server. A Host Guardian Service client in Secure Hosting Service mode uses the server that this parameter specifies.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
An HGS client configuration object containing information about the operating mode, configured URLs, and result of the most recent attestation attempt, if applicable.

command:example.maml:title: --------- Example 1: Set an attestation and key protection servers ---------

maml:introduction.maml:para: ``` PS C:\> Set-HgsClientConfiguration -AttestationServerUrl "https://DemoHgs.Contoso.com/Attestation" -KeyProtectionServerUrl "https://DemoHgs.Contoso.com/KeyProtection" ```
This command configures the URLs used by the attestation client and the key protection client. Use this command to configure the local host to run in Host Guardian Service mode.

command:example.maml:title: --------- Example 2: Change the mode to Local ---------

maml:introduction.maml:para: ``` PS C:\> Set-HgsClientConfiguration -EnableLocalMode ```
This command changes the Host Guardian Service client from Host Guardian Service mode to Local mode. This command resets the attestation server URL and the key protection server URL.

maml:description.maml:para: Forces the HGS client to attest against the configured attestation servers.

The **Test-HgsClientConfiguration** cmdlet forces the HGS client to attest against an HGS server and report back on the attestation attempt. Any cached attestation health certificates from recent attestation attempts will be ignored.
Specifies that the HGS client should only attest against the primary attestation server.
Specifies that the HGS client should only attest against the fallback attestation server.
Specifies that the HGS client should only attest against the fallback attestation server.
Specifies that the HGS client should only attest against the primary attestation server.
An object containing the attestation server URL used and the results of the attestation attempt.

maml:introduction.maml:para: ``` PS C:\> Test-HgsClientConfiguration ```
Performs an attestation attempt using the primary HGS server. If the primary HGS server cannot be reached and fallback URLs are configured, the fallback HGS server will be used.
``` PS C:\> Test-HgsClientConfiguration -UsePrimary ```
Performs an attestation attempt using the primary HGS server. If the primary HGS server cannot be reached, the cmdlet will fail.
``` PS C:\> Test-HgsClientConfiguration -UseFallback ```
Performs an attestation attempt using the fallback HGS server.
